is a small town in the south of
, and is the state's southernmost municipality.

Founded in 1666, and once the second most populous city in the state (while now having a population under 3,000!) Crisfield plays an outsized role in the Eastern Shore's sense of self. Its well-known moniker, the

, seems a little dated, now that farm run off from the Chesapeake Watershed has devastated the regions seafood hauls, but it remains one of the principal centers of Chesapeake Waterman culture.
While Crisfield is

less tourist-oriented than some of the charming small towns of the southern Eastern Shoreâ€”it's a gritty port town and a little rough around the edges, it's still a good visit for the authentic Chesapeake Bay culture (and is well combined with a day trip to
), as well as some seafood dining, or the state's famous
.  At the 50/13 split take 13 and proceed past
, take US-13N until you reach MD-413S.
is the largest marina in Maryland, and has plenty of available docking, as well as public departures for
, M-F, with stops at Somers Cove, the McDonalds, and the high school.
follows a similar route on Sundays.
There are no commercial flights available, but you can always park your private plane at Crisfield Municipal Airport.

value: directions=At the waterfront in Somers Cove Marina
hours=Memorial Day-30 Oct: M-F 9AM-4:30PM, Sa-Su 10AM-3PM; 1 Nov-Memorial Day: M-F 9AM-4:30PM, Sa-Su closed
content=The museum is dedicated to the history of the local Watermen, early Maryland Colonial history, and, somewhat jarringly, decoy carving and painting! The very worthwhile
takes off from here, which includes a tour of a working crab/oyster processing plant.

content=This park is a real hidden gem, in no small part because you have to take a boat to get there. Miles of isolated beaches on a beautiful island on the Bay. Opportunities for kayaking/canoeing on multitudinous water trails, fishing, crabbing, and, of course, swimming!
name=Gov. J. Millard Tawes Crab and Clam Bake
content=It is what the name says, and it has been a delicious little festival for 30 years.
content=Everything quirky and crabby, from shucking contests to parades to the ever consequential matter of choosing Maryland's little Miss and Mr Crustacean.

content=A great mix of local seafood and Southern cuisine, where everything is home made and made to order. The all lump crab cakes (considered some of the best in the region) as well as the fried chicken are standouts. Don't skip the Smith Island ten-layer cake for dessert.
hours=Lunch and dinner Th-Su year round, W-Su in July-Aug

content=Simple but attractive, very unpretentious, and very reasonably priced, this is a great option for seafood in Crisfield. Friendly staff and great seafood at small town prices is a winning combination. Reservations recommended.

content=My Fair Lady is pretty clearly the best accommodations in Crisfield, in a nice, well-maintained Victorian home furnished with antiques. Troella, the owner, will help you figure out your local plans, and cooks a mean breakfast!
